July 12, 1992: Fiction
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student seeks to discover the truth about the murder of two Supreme Court
justices.
SCRUPLES TWO, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $22.) Continuing the story of the
crowd that frequents an ultrachic Beverly Hills store.
WAITING TO EXHALE, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $22.) The friendships and
romances of four black women in Phoenix.
DARK FORCE RISING, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $18.50.) An insane
Jedi threatens Luke Skywalker in the second volume of a "Star Wars" trilogy.
JEWELS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $23.) The life of a woman who becomes
rich by dealing in precious stones.
POSSESSING THE SECRET OF JOY, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $19.95.) The struggles of an African woman to come to terms with the
consequences of female circumcision.
SAHARA, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) On a mission to Africa, Dirk
Pitt uncovers a plot that may extinguish all life in the world's seas.
ALL AROUND THE TOWN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) The
plight of a college student accused of killing her professor.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
DOUBLE DEUCE, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $19.95.) Spenser joins his old
friend Hawk to investigate murders in a Boston housing project.
THE ROAD TO OMAHA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $23.95.) A retired
general and a lawyer scheme to take possession of Nebraska on behalf of an
obscure Indian tribe.
JAZZ, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $21.) A couple in the Harlem of the 1920's learn
again and again that life does not keep its promises.
ALL THE PRETTY HORSES, by Cormac McCarthy. (Knopf, $21.) The adventures
of a 16-year-old vaquero from Texas in the Mexico of 1950.
RISING SUN, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $22.) The mysterious death of a young
woman leads to an investigation in which technology and the American-Japanese
rivalry play major roles.
"I" IS FOR INNOCENT, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $18.95.) Kinsey Millhone
Non-Fiction
DIANA: HER TRUE STORY, by Andrew Morton. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A
biography of the Princess of Wales.
THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The
psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women.
TRUMAN, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A biography of the 33d
President.
SAM WALTON: MADE IN AMERICA, by Sam Walton with John Huey.
(Doubleday, $22.50.) The autobiography of the man who became the richest
American by creating the Wal-Mart store chain.
PEROT, by Todd Mason. (Business One Irwin, $16.95.) An unauthorized
biography of Ross Perot, by a reporter for The Wall Street Journal.
DIANA IN PRIVATE, by Lady Colin Campbell. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A biography
of the Princess of Wales.
HEAD TO HEAD, by Lester Thurow. (Morrow, $25.) An economist considers the
upcoming economic battle among Japan, Europe and the United States.
A BRILLIANT MADNESS, by Patty Duke and Gloria Hochman. (Bantam, $22.50.)
The actress tells how she learned to live with manic-depressive illness.
GIVE WAR A CHANCE, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Atlantic Monthly, $20.95.) Satirical
essays on recent social and political developments.
ACQUIRED TASTES, by Peter Mayle. (Bantam, $20.) Essays on the pleasures of
living extravagantly during the high-flying 1980's.
REVOLUTION FROM WITHIN, by Gloria Steinem. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The
reflections of a feminist on the struggle to achieve self-esteem.
BACKLASH, by Susan Faludi. (Crown, $24.) A journalist contends that the media
and political groups are staging a war against women's rights.
ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, by Blanche Wiesen Cook. (Viking, $27.50.) From
childhood in New York to the White House: the first 49 years of a pre-eminent First
Lady.
WHO WILL TELL THE PEOPLE, by William Greider. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A
journalist's account of how powerful monied interests and elite groups dominate
the Federal Government.
CHIEF, by Daryl F. Gates with Diane K. Shah. (Bantam, $22.50.) The
autobiography of the man who headed the Los Angeles Police Department for 14
